author: bridge-bot
content:
<kevaundray> > <kevaundray>  Maybe the EIP itself would be more helpful as to how its being used?

My understanding is that:

- 4844 requires you to commit to data; this requires _some_ commitment scheme
- The data is being viewed as a polynomial. This therefore allows one to use a polynomial commitment scheme (PCS)
- The PCS that has been chosen is called KZG
- This particular PCS requires a object with a particular structure, that everyone can refer to when proving/verifying; this object is known as the structured reference string (SRS)
- This SRS needs to be generated by multiple people who do not collude for it to be deemed "safe/secure" to use.
- The generation of the srs by multiple people is what we call the ceremony/trusted setup (re @kzg_ceremony_bot: <Trent Van Epps> i linked @Kev's document here, https://hackmd.io/@6iQDuIePQjyYBqDChYw_jg/SJ-08AoT5

but it only touches on ceremony >> SRS briefly. are there better resources that outline why 4844 requires a ceremony / how 4844 uses the SRSs?)

author: kevaundray
content:
> Will the site be a static site deployed to IPFS?

This was not originally planned, though I looked up how to do it and its relatively straightforward once the frontend has been finalised

One alternative which _is_ included, is for users to build the site locally and contribute using a local build, though this is solving a slightly different problem than the one you are referring to.

> And will the build for that site be deterministic (so one can reproduce it from source and verify the IPFS hash?

I've not looked into deterministic builds, but I'm assuming that fixing the frontend dependencies and using a .wasm file that was generated using a specific gcc/clang version should be all that is needed. (AFAIK no thought has gone into deterministic frontend builds)

> And will that site make the minimum number of requests to the coordinator to complete the transaction and no more?

Yep, though because there is a polling mechanism, not every contributor will make the same amount of requests. (I could poll the sequencer once, get the spot to contribute, contribute, then I am done. Or I could poll and only get the contribution spot after 10 minutes)
